docs.studentDialog:
Here is a short story. I want you to read this aloud.  When you finish, I will ask you some questions about what you have read.  Do you understand what are you supposed to do?

When I say “begin,” read the story as best as you can. I will keep quiet and listen to you, unless you need help. Ready? Begin.
docs.enumeratorHelp:
Show the child the story in the stimuli booklet. Read the instructions to the child and conduct the examples.  

Start the timer when the child reads the first word.

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect word by touching that word on the screen - it will turn blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the word again - it will return to grey. 

Stay quiet, except if the child hesitates for 3 seconds. Then point to the next word and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped word as incorrect.

If the timer runs out before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final word read by touching it so that a red bracket appears, then press “Next”.

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last word. If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The bracket will automatically appear on the last word.  Verify your scores, and then press "Next".

Early stop rule: If the child does not read a single word correctly from among the words necessary to answer the first comprehension question, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
docs.name: EGRA Task 5A. Oral Reading Fluency Passage
docs.transitionComment: REMOVE THE READING PASSAGE FROM IN FRONT OF THE CHILD before pressing 'Next'.

docs.studentDialog:
Student stimulus sheet EGMA F1-B1

Look at these numbers. [Indicate Example #1, the numbers 10 and 4.]  Tell me which number is bigger.
[if correct]
That’s correct, 10 is bigger. Let’s do another one.
[if incorrect]
The bigger number is 10. [Point to 10] This is 10. [Point to 4] This is 4.  10 is bigger than 4. Let’s do another one.
 

Look at these numbers. [Indicate Example #2, the numbers 8 and 12.] Tell me which number is bigger.
[if correct]
That’s right, 12 is bigger.  Let’s continue.
[if incorrect]
The bigger number is 12. [Point to 8] This number is 8. [Point to 12] This is 12.  12 is bigger than 8. Let’s continue.
docs.enumeratorHelp:
Student stimulus sheets EGMA F1-B1 (example), F1-B2 (exercise) and F1-B3 (exercise)

Show the child the sheet in the student stimulus booklet as you read the instructions. 
Follow along on your screen and mark any item as either correct or incorrect. Your selected answer will turn yellow.

If the child makes 4 successive errors, the screen will "grey out" any remaining items. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS, point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.
docs.name: EGMA Task 2. Quantity Discrimination
